title: Adsorption and separation of carbon dioxide and methane in new zeolites using the Grand Canonical Monte Carlo method
text: mixtures is a challenging research topic due to environmental and economic concerns, and the inherent difficulties in conducting experiments. There are several technologies applied for the separation of mixtures of CH
), in which adsorption-based processes are widely used for post-combustion CO
), the purification of biogas (Alonso-Vicario et al.
), and the purification of coal mine methane and coal mine ventilation air (VAM) (Olajossy et al.
). The reason is that the separation cost is usually low if the separation is based on the difference of components in adsorption (Ruthven et al.
). Furthermore, the adsorbent is a decisive factor of feasibility and separation cost. In a cost-effective manner, zeolites are considered as potential sorbents for the adsorption of CH
Zeolites have been intensively investigated in recent decades because of their large surface areas and molecular sized porous structures (Zhang et al.
). They are an important class of materials in which separations are obtained by selecting the pore size such that in mixtures molecules that are too large are blocked (Smit and Maesen
). Therefore, zeolites are widely used in applications such as separation, purification, ion exchange, catalysis and the isolation of biological molecular (Krishna and van Baten
). Currently, about 200 types of zeolite have been crystallographically classified and several new types still appear every year (Liu et al.
). Thus, studies on the adsorption and separation behaviors for CH
mixtures in new zeolites are very important and attractive from the viewpoints of science and their applications.

However, zeolites are also challenging because it is very difficult to carry out experiments that provide us with information at the molecular level. In this respect, molecular simulations nicely complement experiments (Catlow et al.

). With the development of computer technology, molecular simulation methods, such as Grand Canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC), are playing an important role in developing our understanding of the relationship between the microscopic and macroscopic properties of molecular fluids confined in zeolites, and can be used to generate adsorption isotherms for gases on microporous solid adsorbents (Liu et al.
). To date, the adsorption of water/methanol and water/ethanol mixtures in zeolite 4A was simulated using the GCMC simulation (Wu et al.
S removal from biogas streams using different zeolites such as NaX, NaY, LTA and MFI with the GCMC method. Pham et al. (Pham et al.

in pure silica zeolites (BEA, CHA, FER, MFI, and STT) experimentally and by GCMC simulation, and the agreement between computed adsorption isotherms and isosteric heats with those found experimentally was excellent. The Calero group investigated the adsorption selectivity of CO
in MFI, MOR, ISV, ITE, CHA and DDR (García-Pérez et al.

). The results showed that the selectivity behavior strongly depended on the type of material structure and the bulk composition of the mixture. Therefore, molecular simulations have become a powerful tool to explore both materials science and life science fields (Zeng et al.
In this work, the adsorption and separation properties for CO

, and the selectivity performance of new siliceous zeolites (IFO, JSR, SEW and OKO) were investigated using the molecular simulation method, which would quickly aid in choosing effective adsorbents for gas adsorption and separation, and could be practically important for gas separation from low-concentration mine gas.

New zeolites are discovered and synthesized annually. Their adsorption, separation and selectivity properties are worth investigating and can be a fascinating area of research. Therefore, the separation of CO
in four new siliceous zeolites (IFO, JSR, OKO and SEW) was investigated using the GCMC method. Framework structures of the new siliceous zeolites are shown in Fig.
, and details of the different zeolite structures used in the calculations are listed in Table
Framework structures of new siliceous zeolites
The Grand Canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) method was employed in this work (Metropolis et al.

), which is widely applied in the study of adsorption problems. The GCMC method uses a grand canonical ensemble, in which the chemical potential of each species, the volume of the system and the temperature are fixed (Agnihotri et al.

). Hence, comparisons between simulation results and experimental data are reasonable because the adsorption conditions (pressure and temperature) are also constant in the experiments (Rahmati and Modarress
In the present work, each zeolite framework was considered to be rigid. All interactions of gas–zeolite and gas–gas were modeled using the PCFF force field (Hill and Sauer
). The PCFF has been proved as a powerful force field supporting for adsorption in many zeolite systems (Song et al.

). The cutoff distance for the calculation of the van der Waals potential energy by an atom based technique was taken as 1.3 nm. The partial charges of atoms were estimated by the charge-equilibration method (Rappe and Goddard
) and the electrostatic energy was calculated using the Ewald summation method (Karasawa and Goddard
) with an accuracy of 0.0001 kcal mol

. The partial pressure required for describing the chemical potential of the adsorbed molecules was calculated using the ideal gas law. In the GCMC simulation, adsorbate molecules in the zeolite were translated, rotated, created and deleted from the zeolite framework at random with a probability of 0.225, 0.225, 0.275 and 0.275, respectively (Rahmati and Modarress
steps were used to achieve equilibration and the last 5 × 10
steps were used for calculation of the required properties and subsequent data analysis. For the MFI-type zeolite, the supercell consists of 8 unit cells (2 × 2 × 2,
= 1.342 nm). Periodic boundary conditions were applied in three-dimensions in order to simulate an infinite system. Further details of the GCMC method can be found in the literature (Dubbeldam et al.
To verify the simulation techniques, the adsorption isotherms of CO
in the MFI zeolite were compared to experimental data (Babarao et al.

. A good agreement between the simulation results and experimental data was found based on the adsorption isotherms, which demonstrated that the simulation techniques were satisfactory for the simulation of CO
adsorption in purely siliceous zeolites. Therefore, the simulation techniques were applied in the adsorption studies for CO
in the IFO, JSR, OKO and SEW zeolites.

in the four zeolite structures at 298 K are shown in Fig.
. The results show that the adsorbed amount of each pure component increases with an increase in pressure, and the sequence for the adsorption amount of CO
in these zeolites is JSR > SEW > OKO > IFO. The adsorption amount of CO
adsorbed in the JSR zeolite is 7.08 and 2.27 mmol g
at 1000 kPa, respectively. Comparing with NaX, NaY, MFI, CHA and DDR zeolites, the adsorption amount of CO
is higher than that in NaX, NaY, CHA or DDR, whereas the adsorption amount of CH
is smaller than that in these zeolites, and the adsorption amount of CO
in the MFI zeolite is only 2.89 and 2.05 mmol g
). On the other hand, for RWY, STW, SOF, PUN, STO, SSF, LTF, IWS, ITR, SVR, BSV and SFS zeolites (Rahmati and Modarress
), the maximum adsorption amount of CO
and the minimum adsorption amount of CH
in the these zeolites is 3.78 and 1.36 mmol g
at 1000 kPa, respectively. Thus, JSR zeolite is a better adsorbent for the separation of CO
mixture among these zeolites because it has higher CO
adsorption amount and equilibrium adsorption amount ratio between CO
is higher than that of CH

is a more slender molecule than CH
and the energy barrier for inter-cage hopping is lower than that for CH
). Therefore, the steric hindrance in the CH
molecule is greater than that of CO

The pore volume and surface area are very important parameters to understand the adsorption and diffusion behavior of penetrated molecules in nanoporous materials. In this work, the pore volume and surface area characterization of the zeolites were analyzed by the Connolly surface method (
). The probe molecule was selected using hard spheres with a radius of 0.165 nm (the kinetic radius of CO
). The simulated results for the pore volume and surface area were summarized in Table
, the magnitude of the pore volume and surface area can be ranked as follows: JSR > SEW > OKO > IFO, which is consistent with the adsorption capacity for CO
. The result indicates that larger pore volume and surface area are beneficial to improve gas adsorption capacity in zeolites.
The free volume and surface area of new siliceous zeolites

The adsorption process is always accompanied by changes in the system for Gibb’s free energy, enthalpy and entropy, which are favorable to understand the adsorption mechanism and the interactions between adsorbents and adsorbates. The thermodynamic parameters of Gibb’s free energy change, Δ
, for the adsorption process were calculated using the following equations:

The adsorption isotherms for equimolar mixtures of CO
in IFO, JSR, OKO and SEW at 298 K are shown in Fig.
. With an increase in pressure, the amount of CO
adsorbed initially increases linearly and then flattens, while the amount of CH
adsorbed changes little. The ratios of equilibrium adsorption capacity for the equimolar mixtures at different pressures are presented in Table
. It is obvious that with an increase in pressure, the ratio of equilibrium adsorption capacity for CO

increases. For a pressure swing adsorption (PSA) processes, the adsorption step generally takes place at moderate pressures (5 atm) in view of energy saving. In this condition, the equilibrium adsorption capacities for CO
in all zeolites were five times more than those for CH
, which suggests that the new siliceous zeolites have a strong ability to separate a mixture of CO

The GCMC method was employed to investigate the adsorption and separation properties for CO
in new siliceous zeolites of IFO, JSR, OKO and SEW. The adsorption isotherms for the pure components and binary mixtures of CO
in these zeolites were obtained. Adsorption thermodynamic parameters were also analyzed.
The adsorbed amount of pure components increases with an increase in pressure and the adsorption amount for both CO
in these zeolites can be ranked as follows: JSR > SEW > OKO > IFO. The adsorption amount of CO
in the JSR zeolite is 7.08 and 2.27 mmol g
at 1000 kPa, respectively. The thermodynamic parameters of Gibb’s free energy change and enthalpy change of adsorption show that CO
displays a higher affinity than that of CH
in the new siliceous zeolites. A negative adsorption entropy change Δ
adsorbed are in an ordered arrangement in all the new zeolites. The more negative entropy for CO
in each new zeolite presents a more orderly arrangement of CO
The adsorption isotherms for the binary mixtures suggest the new siliceous zeolites can be used to separate a CO
mixture. Considering the adsorption uptake and selectivity for CO
, the JSR zeolite is a good candidate for the separation of CO
